abstract.p: Robert E Griffin letter on peacekeeping in Sierra Leone; points to US resistance to forming standing UN peacekeeping force

block.p: ''The War in Sierra Leone'' (editorial, May 12) ignores the systemic problem of international peacekeeping: We have not empowered the United Nations to possess a volunteer standing peacekeeping force that could rapidly and effectively respond to regional conflicts.

National political concerns, here and elsewhere, about casualties result in the failure of ad hoc peacekeeping forces. The forces provided by individual countries upon request of the secretary general usually end up being too little, too late.

''The War in Sierra Leone'' (editorial, May 12) ignores the systemic problem of international peacekeeping: We have not empowered the United Nations to possess a volunteer standing peacekeeping force that could rapidly and effectively respond to regional conflicts.

National political concerns, here and elsewhere, about casualties result in the failure of ad hoc peacekeeping forces. The forces provided by individual countries upon request of the secretary general usually end up being too little, too late.

The United States has resisted international attempts to form a standing United Nations peacekeeping force out of concerns of sovereignty. These fears have been fanned by those like Senator Jesse Helms. The price of such thinking is paid in blood by innocent civilians who didn't have the good luck of being born in a country where there is democracy.
ROBERT E. GRIFFIN Forty Fort, Pa., May 12, 2000
